BC-PHOTO-FULL-UPDATE-NYT 
   ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving Monday, 08/16/99. Photo
clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's
PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo
Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at
305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling
(888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT21) UNDATED -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- COLLEGE-ONLINE, 08-16 --
Starting Tuesday, when students at Appalachian State University
check their e-mail or course outlines online, they will be looking
at advertising from dozens of companies including Amazon.com, Dell
Computer and an apartment-locator service called SpringStreet. The
placement of advertising on what some regard as the purest area of
the Internet - the educational domain - has spurred an acrimonious
debate. (New York Times Photo)

   (NYT20) MOUNT PLEASANT, N.Y. -- Aug. 16, 1999 --
DROUGHT-FOLIAGE, 08-16 -- Across New England and into New York, the
drought has leaves turning color prematurely. This tree is in Mount
Pleasant. (Joyce Dopkeen/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT19) LOS ANGELES -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- MCCAIN-CAMPAIGN, 08-16
-- Sen. John McCain of Arizona, a Republican Presidential hopeful,
with a member of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith in Los
Angeles on Monday. ``When we stand on a soapbox and denounce Jerry
Springer, and then go to the floor of Congress and behave like
guests on his show, it's little wonder that the American public has
long since stopped looking to us for guidance or leadership,'' he
says. (Monica Almeida/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT18) ARCADIA, Mich. -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- GOLF-ENVIRON, 08-16
-- The Arcadia Bluffs golf course sits above Lake Michigan. Critics
say its design will further erosion. (John R. Williams/New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT17) NEW YORK -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- CAREERS-FASHION-4, 08-16 --
Mary Ann Restivo with some of the scarves from her new collection.
The Restivo label, a mainstay of the career woman in the 1980s,
succumbed to the changing fashion market in the early '90s, after
it was sold to a large company. ``I plan to do evening bags to go
with the scarves, and maybe shoes,'' says Ms. Restivo who, after
seven years as a freelance consultant, has gone into the scarf
business. (Linda Rosier/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT16) NEW YORK -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- CAREERS-FASHION-3, 08-16 --
Charlotte Neuville, seated, with a model in designs from her resort
collection for New York & Co. Ms. Neuville shuttered her signature
line in 1992 after seven years, and is now Lerner New York's vice
president for design where, in a little more than three years, she
has transformed the tired brand into a trendy line. ``Being handed
this opportunity has been like having my own business without
worrying about the bills,'' she says. (Linda Rosier/New York Times
Photo) LITE

   (NYT15) SAFETY HARBOR, Fla. -- Aug. 16, 1999 --
CAREERS-FASHION-2, 08-16 -- Michaele Vollbracht in his Florida
studio. ``I had a great 15 minutes,'' says Vollbracht, who made his
name with boldly patterned evening wear before walking out on his
fashion company a decade ago and moving to Safety Harbor. ``Now, I
cultivate bamboo.'' (Ricardo J. Ferro/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT14) NEW YORK -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- CAREERS-FASHION-1, 08-16 --
Christian Francis Roth with a color-block shirt from his fall
collection for QVC. Roth, who created a stir a decade ago at the
age of 20 with inventive ideas like dresses that looked like dollar
bills before losing his financial backers, is looking to revive his
designer business. ``My first collection for QVC debuted in May and
sold out in half an hour,'' he says. (Linda Rosier/New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT13) STOLAC, Bosnia-Herzegovina -- Aug. 16, 1999 --
BOSNIA-CORRUPTION-2, 08-16 -- The Stolac used car market, that
convenes every Sunday in the Croat-controlled part of Bosnia, has
one of the largest collections of stolen vehicles in Europe,
according to international police. On one Sunday some four hundred
cars, most with forged registration papers and German, Swiss and
Italian license plates were being sold for large wads of German
Deutsche Marks. (Alan Chin/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT12) STOLAC, Bosnia-Herzegovina -- Aug. 16, 1999 --
BOSNIA-CORRUPTION-1, 08-16 -- The Stolac used car market, that
convenes every Sunday in the Croat-controlled part of Bosnia, has
one of the largest collections of stolen vehicles in Europe,
according to international police. As much as a billion dollars has
disappeared from public funds or been stolen from international aid
projects through corruption, kick-backs and fraud carried out by
the Muslim, Croat and Serb nationalist leaders who keep Bosnia
rigidly partitioned. (Alan Chin/New York Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT11) WASHINGTON -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- BAUER-PROFILE, 08-16 --
Gary L. Bauer works the phones from his Washington office after his
fourth-place finish in Iowa's straw poll. Best known for his
advocacy of conservative religious values as the former president
of the Family Research Council, Bauer seizes every opportunity to
remind voters that he worked for six years in various positions
within the Reagan Administration, including as an undersecretary of
education. (Paul Hosefros/New York Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT10) UNDATED -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- SCI-CASSINI-SATURN, 08-16 --
An artist's conception of the Cassini spacecraft as it enters
Saturn's orbit. Cassini is to study the planet, its rings and moons
for four years. (Jet Propulsion Laboratory/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT9) NEW YORK -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- NY-WELFARE-CARD-2, 08-16 --
One of the debit cards issued by Citigroup, a financial
conglomerate hired by New York State to distribute welfare benefits
through ATM cards. In the last few years, 39 states and the
District of Columbia have hired corporations to distribute welfare
benefits through the nation's vast web of ATMs and grocery-store
debit machines. (Librado Romero/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT8) NEW YORK -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- NY-WELFARE-CARD-1, 08-15 --
Margarita O., an 18-year-old illegal immigrant from Mexico, with
her son. She is holding an unusual debit card that gives her access
to $448 a month in government food credits and cash. Unfortunately,
the card is not living up to its expectations. (Angel Franco/New
York Times Photo)

   (NYT7) PEABODY, Mass. -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- SHATNER-KIDD-BOS,
O8-16 -- Warren Kidd browses some family photos as he reflects on
the life of his sister, Nerine Kidd Shatner, who was found dead in
the swimming pool behind her and husband William Shatner's mansion
in Studio City, Calif., on Tuesday. She ``was full of energy,'' he
recalls with a laugh. ``She was like a windup doll that never wound
down.'' (Janet Knott/Boston Globe Photo)

   (NYT6) NEW HAVEN, Conn. -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- SCI-OLDER-COLUMN,
08-16 -- Glenda Hamm reads the paper to Henry Bukowski in his bed
at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. A recent study shows that a series
of simple environmental interventions reduces the risk of delirium
which can occur in elderly patients. The therapy includes backrubs,
warm milk, and making sure that patients had their eyeglasses and
hearing aids, and ingested enough food and liquids to prevent
dehydration and muscle atrophy. (Bill Greene/Boston Globe Photo)

   (NYT5) UNDATED -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- BRODY-HEALTH, 08-16 -- Dr.
Mark Robson, a clinical geneticist, consults with Deborah
McDermott, a genetic counselor, over a patients ``chart.'' The
ability to test for genetic abnormalities that greatly increase a
woman's risk of developing breast or ovarian cancer has created new
and potentially lifesaving options. But it has also raised a host
of new concerns for women with a family history of these cancers.
(Barbara Alper/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT4) FRONT ROYAL, Va. -- Aug. 16, 1999 --
SCI-KEEN-NOSED-DOGS-3, 08-16 -- Dogs are taught to sniff out drugs,
explosives and money at the Customs Service's Canine Enforcement
Training Center in Front Royal. Dogs trained for airport duty -
like this white Labrador retriever - must be good at detecting
contraband in luggage without appearing menacing. (Michael
Geissinger/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT3) FRONT ROYAL, Va. -- Aug. 16, 1999 --
SCI-KEEN-NOSED-DOGS-2, 08-16 -- A rolled towel saturated with the
scent of a pseudonarcotic is used to teach the dogs how to detect
smuggled drugs at the Customs Service's Canine Enforcement Training
Center in Front Royal. ``In their mind, they're looking for the
towel,'' says Tim Spittler, a canine enforcement officer here.
``They don't think they're looking for narcotics.'' (Michael
Geissinger/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT2) FRONT ROYAL, Va. -- Aug. 16, 1999 --
SCI-KEEN-NOSED-DOGS-1, 08-16 -- Just 8-weeks-old, this puppy is
already on a career path at the Customs Service's Canine
Enforcement Training Center in Front Royal, where dogs are taught
to sniff out drugs, explosives and money. The Customs Service
recruits about 1,000 dogs a year, 90 percent of whom are plucked
from animal shelters. (Michael Geissinger/New York Times Photo)
LITE

   (NYT1) UNDATED -- Aug. 16, 1999 -- SCI-SKIN-PATCHES, 08-16 --
Alza, located in Palo Alto, Calif., devised the technology behind
the first patch drug, scopolamine, marketed in 1979 for the
prevention of motion sickness, after a decade of research devoted
to the not-so-simple task of getting a drug molecule smoothly
through the skin. Despite 30 years of research into the subject,
fewer than a dozen drugs are available in skin patches. (New York
Times Photo)

   The New York Times News Service
